articles.title: About the data
articles.contents:
Variables

Variables
Explanations
Date
Date of occurrence in datetime format (time is default 00:00:00.000Z)
StateOfOccurrence
Country of occurrence
Location
City or nearest city of occurrence
Model
Aircraft type
Registration
Aircraft registration code
Operator
Name of Operator (airline, institution or responsible for the aircraft operation)
StateOfOperator
Operator’s country
StateOfRegistry
Country of aircraft registration
FlightPhase
Flight Phase of occurrence (take off, landing, approach, etc.)
Class
Accident (unique value). rmk: only ‘Accident’ class was selected in this dataset (no incidens)
Fatalities
Number of fatal victims
Over2250
If aircraft basic operational weight (empty) is greater than 2250KG
Over5700
If aircraft basic operational weight (empty) is greater than 5700KG
ScheduledCommercial
If it was a scheduled commercial flight (airlines mostly)
InjuryLevel
Level of injuries on person/people involved in the occurrence
TypeDesignator
Aircraft type code (https://cfapps.icao.int/doc8643/reports/Part2-By%20Type%20Designator(Decode).pdf)
Helicopter
if it was a helicopter
Airplane
If it was an airplane
Engine
Number of engines in the aircraft
EngineType
Aircraft engine type (jet, turboprop or piston)
Official
If ICAO was designated to participate in the accident investigation
OccCats
All risk types involved in the occurrence, coded according to HRCs ( High Risks Categories codes) - ICAO
Risk
Main risk type involved in the occurrence, coded according to HRCs(( High Risks Categories codes) - ICAO
Year
Year of occurrence

Data Preparation
Here are the packages I used for this data visualization:


library(dplyr)
library(tidyverse)
library(knitr)


Read the data:


df<-read.csv("data/ICAO_accidents.csv") 

#Country abbreviation to country full name
world <- read.csv("data/world.csv") %>% 
    rename(StateOfOccurrence = Abbreviation)
df <- left_join(df, world)


We are only looking at the accidents of commercial flights:


com <- filter(df, df$ScheduledCommercial == "True") %>% select(Year, Country, Model, Fatalities, Over2250, Over5700, InjuryLevel, Risk, FlightPhase, EngineType)
kable(head(com[1:4,]))

coun<- com %>% group_by(Country, na.rm = T) %>% mutate(num_fatal = sum(Fatalities, na.rm = T))


Add up the fatality number for each year for each Flight Phase:

            Reason of the interest
            On 2022 March, there are a flight accident in China
            occurred on the route to my city, Guangzhou. The whole
            country were in sadness because of the flight tragedy. As
            human beings, we can easily imagine that the love ones of
            those travelers who were waiting at the destination city
            were heart-broken. Therefore, I want to analyze the data to
            visualize what factors lead to flight accidents based on the
            public data, what dangerous factors we can avoid to get a
            safer trip. Therefore, I intentionally selected the recent
            15 years (2008-2022) flight accident data to illustrate.
            
            
            About the Data Source
            For this project, I used data from Kaggle by searchign term
            “flight accidents.” You can download the complete dataset here,
            which contains 6109 flight accidents information in recent
            15 years. The dataset include 26 variables, e.g., location,
            year, number of fatality, flight operator, injury level
            etc.. The original data is extracted from from ICAO
            (International Civil Aviation Organization) API, occurred in
            the last 15 years (from Jan 2008 to May 2022). Original ICAO
            API datasets link is available here.
            API key required, with 100 free calls available using a
            company email for subscription.
            
            
            Audience
            The intended audience of this visualization is for
            general travelers who care about flight safety. The
            visualization should not require any knowledge background to
            interpret.
            
            
            Research Questions:
            Which phases during the flight is the most easy to cause
            accidents?
            Where is the location is the most frequent to have
            flight accidents?
            What factors create the most fatal number in the flight
            accidents?

articles.title: Number of Accidents Each Year and Risk Factors
articles.description: The data visualization represent the number of accidents from 2008 to 2022 and represents the risk factor of the accidents.
articles.contents:
fig



Please see the abbreviation in the Risk Factor Hand Book
This plot represents the number of accidents (from 2008 - 2022) each year and the risk factor of the accidents based on the result of aviation occurrence investigation.The x axis represents the year from 2008 to 2022, and the y axis represents the number of accidents. The risk factors are represented by the colors on the line plot. In the interactive graph, readers can click on to see the actual accidents number for the year. From this plot, we can easily distinguish that most of accidents occurred because of “Runway Safety”, and there are most accidents happened in 2014. And we can see the accidents are lower by years.
This plot is intended for a general audience. See the plots on the below for different iterations of this visualization.

articles.title: Year and Fatal Number in different Flight Phase
articles.description: The data visualization represent the number of fatalities from 2008 to 2022 in different flight phase.
articles.contents:
plot





This plot represents the number of fatalities (from 2008 - 2022) each year from across different flight phase (i.e., from Approach to Landing). The x axis represents the year from 2008 to 2022, and the y axis represents the number of fatal number. The group of flight phase are represented on the facet. From this plot, we can easily distinguish that in 2014, flights cause more fatal number during the flight. The flight phase causes the most fatal is En-Route. That is why we need to keep our sit bell on during the flight.
This plot is intended for a general audience. See the plots on the below for different iterations of this visualization.

articles.title: World Map
articles.description: 2008-2012 Numbers of Flight Accidents in the world
articles.contents:
worldmap 



This plot represents the number of flight accidents cases (from 2008 - 2022) across the world for each country in the dataset, only with fatalities. The number of the flight accidents is represented by the color fill in the worldmap. The color closer to red means more cases occurred. From this plot, we can easily distinguish that Russia had the highest number of cases from 2008 to 2022. Additionally, more flight accidents occurred in China and Russia compared to the other countries during the time frame.
This plot is intended for a general audience. See the plots on the below for different iterations of this visualization.
